revision.comment: Moving [[:Category:Ghana Secondary Technical School Alumni]] to [[:Category:Ghana Secondary Technical School alumni]] per [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Speedy]]
revision.text:
{{short description|Ghanaian engineer}} {{EngvarB|date=November 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2019}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Ashitey Trebi-Ollennu | honorific_suffix = [[Institution of Engineering and Technology|FIET]], [[Royal Aeronautical Society|FRAeS]], [[Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers|SMIEE]], [[Project Management Professional|PMP]], [[Ghana Academy of Arts and Sciences|FGA]] | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Accra]], [[Ghana]] | death_date = | death_place = | other_names = | nationality = [[Ghanaian]] | fields = {{hlist|[[Avionics]]|[[Control engineering]]|[[Robotics]]}} | workplaces = [[NASA]] [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] at [[Caltech]] | known_for = {{hlist|[[Mars Rover]]|[[InSight|InSight Mars Mission]]}} | thesis_title = Robust Non-linear Control Designs Using Adaptive Fuzzy Systems | education = {{unbulleted list|[[Ghana Secondary Technical School]]|[[Queen Mary, University of London]] ([[Bachelor of Engineering|BEng]])|[[Cranfield University]] ([[PhD]])|[[California Institute of Technology]] ([[Project Management Professional|PMP]])}} }}
'''Ashitey Trebi-Ollennu,''' {{post nominals|post-noms=[[Institution of Engineering and Technology|FIET]], [[Royal Aeronautical Society|FRAeS]], [[Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers|SMIEE]], [[Project Management Professional|PMP]], [[Ghana Academy of Arts and Sciences|FGA]]}} is a [[Ghana]]ian robotics engineer at the [[NASA|National Aeronautics and Space Administration]] (NASA) and the [[chief engineer]] and technical group leader for the mobility and manipulation group at the [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]]<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.starrfmonline.com/1.1967861# |title=Archived copy |access-date=29 January 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150129074453/http://starrfmonline.com/1.1967861# |archive-date=29 January 2015 |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/av/technology-40306617/five-robots-that-are-changing-everything# |title=Five robots that are changing everything |access-date=22 June 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180808121953/https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/av/technology-40306617/five-robots-that-are-changing-everything# |archive-date=8 August 2018 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/NewsArchive/Meet-the-Ghanaian-scientist-who-built-InSight-NASA-s-latest-spacecraft-to-land-on-Mars-704571|title=Meet the Ghanaian scientist who built InSight, NASA's latest spacecraft to land on Mars|website=www.ghanaweb.com|language=en|access-date=29 November 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181129205220/https://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/NewsArchive/Meet-the-Ghanaian-scientist-who-built-InSight-NASA-s-latest-spacecraft-to-land-on-Mars-704571|archive-date=29 November 2018|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.modernghana.com/news/277627/profile-of-dr-ashitey-trebi-ollennu.html|title=Profile of Dr Ashitey Trebi-Ollennu|last=Newspaper|first=The Timeline|work=Modern Ghana|access-date=29 November 2018|language=en-GB|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181129205222/https://www.modernghana.com/news/277627/profile-of-dr-ashitey-trebi-ollennu.html|archive-date=29 November 2018|url-status=live}}</ref> He has been associated with various NASA Mars missions, notably the [[Mars rover|Mars Rover]] and [[InSight]] projects.
== Early life and education == Ashitey Trebi-Ollennu was born in [[Accra|Accra, Ghana]], to [[Ga-Adangbe people|Ga]] parents. Ollennu's father, Trebi Ollennu was an economist at the Ministry of Finance in Accra. As a child, Ashitey lived close to an airport and would always see airplanes fly by. This fascinated him and caused his interest in [[space exploration]], [[aircraft]] and [[Aerobot|aerial robots]], particularly [[autopilot]]s. He read a lot on the "[[Glass cockpit|Glass Cockpit]]" system for both military and civil airplanes.<ref name=":1" /> He completed his secondary education at the [[Ghana Secondary Technical School]].<ref name=":0" /> He travelled to the United Kingdom where he received his Bachelors in Engineering (BEng) in [[Avionics]] at the [[Queen Mary University of London|Queen Mary, University of London]] in 1991, with a thesis on ''"Review of 4-D guidance techniques and the simulation of 4-D aircraft guidance"''.<ref name=":1" /> Between 1993 and 1996, he pursued his [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]] in [[Control engineering|Control Systems Engineering]] at the School of Engineering and Applied Science, [[Royal Military College of Science]], [[Cranfield University]] in the UK where he wrote his dissertation titled ''"Robust Non-linear Control Designs Using Adaptive Fuzzy Systems.''"<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://www-robotics.jpl.nasa.gov/people/Ashitey_Trebi-Ollennu/|title=JPL Robotics: People: Ashitey Trebi-Ollennu|website=www-robotics.jpl.nasa.gov|access-date=29 November 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170212013204/http://www-robotics.jpl.nasa.gov/people/Ashitey_Trebi-Ollennu/|archive-date=12 February 2017|url-status=live}}</ref> He also holds a [[Project Management Professional|project management certification]] from the [[California Institute of Technology|Caltech]], earned in 2007.<ref name=":2" />
== Career == He joined the NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory in 1999 and rose through the ranks to become the leader of the team that designed the [[Mars rover|Mars Rover]] robot that landed on the red planet. Over the years, his responsibilities have involved flight projects, flight projects review boards, mission formulation, technology tasks, technical writing and proposals. He also served as a reviewer for NASA Science Mission Directorate technology proposals and NASA Office of Education proposals.<ref name=":2"/> Other engagements at NASA are 2003 – [[Mars Exploration Rover]], 2007 – Phoenix Mars Lander and Mars Science Laboratory which is scheduled for launch in 2011 and will be NASA's third generation of rover to explore Mars.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" />
Among his roles at the In Sight Mars Mission were Product Delivery Manager and Chief for the Instrument Deployment System, a technical group lead in the Robotic Manipulation & Sampling group at NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, where he has been since 1999. His technical research interests include on planetary rovers and its operations, system of systems, manipulation, multiple mobile robots (planetary outpost), [[mechatronics]], reconfigurable robots, audjustable autonomy and man-machine interaction.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /> Closely linked to these are various areas in robotics sysems and engineering: Space Robotics Systems, Flight Systems Integration & Test, Planetary Rover Operations, System of Systems Design, Distributed Mobile Robotics, System Architectures, Dynamic Modeling, Control Systems design for Aerospace and Mechatronics Systems and Contract Technical Management.<ref name=":1" /> He has more than 95 publications to his credit.<ref name=":2" />
He was a Research Scholar at the Institute for Complex Engineered Systems at the [[Carnegie Mellon University]] in [[Pittsburgh]] where he was instrumental in the design and implementation of a system of [[All-terrain vehicle|All Terrain Vehicles]] (ATVs) for distributed tactical surveillance for the [[DARPA|Defense Advanced Research Projects Agenc]]<nowiki/>y (DARPA).<ref name=":1" />
In an interview with the [[BBC]], Ashitey Trebi-Ollennu noted that he had started a project in his home country of Ghana to make Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) more likable and fun. He worked on the [[Phoenix (spacecraft)]] that found water on Mars. The [[InSight]] mission successfully landed on the red planet on Monday 26 November 2018.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p02h3hlt#|title=BBC World Service – Exchanges at the Frontier, Exchanges at the Frontier, Robotics|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150126054153/http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p02h3hlt#|archive-date=26 January 2015|url-status=live|access-date=29 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=Edward Balami|title=DR ASHITEY TREBI OLLENNU OF NASA ON STEM|date=13 October 2016|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cHjdywy1zJI|access-date=29 November 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181129205222/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cHjdywy1zJI|archive-date=29 November 2018|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=Wellcome Collection|title=NASA's InSight mission to Mars {{!}} Ashitey Trebi-Ollennu|date=15 January 2015|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ClVXlxV3jjo|access-date=29 November 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181129205222/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ClVXlxV3jjo|archive-date=29 November 2018|url-status=live}}</ref> Per the [[The New York Times|New York Times]], the spacecraft is expected to study the Mars' underworld, listening for [[marsquake]]s and seeking clues about the dusty world's formation.<ref name=":0" />
In 2011 Ashitey founded the Ghana Robotics Academy Foundation (GRAF), a nonprofit volunteer organization dedicated to motivating and inspiring young Ghanaians in science, technology and engineering.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://foundation.ghanarobotics.org/#|title=Ghana Robotics Academy Foundation|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160514122236/http://foundation.ghanarobotics.org/#|archive-date=14 May 2016|url-status=live|access-date=23 May 2016}}</ref> His foundation won the [[Google]] RISE Award 2013.<ref name=":0" />
Commenting on his job, he noted ''"The brilliant thing about my job is that, it is not a circumscribed routine, there are different challenges everyday. Believe me, it is a lot of fun. NASA is also a great organization that cares about its people and their personal development, need I say more?”''<ref name=":1" />
== Honours and awards == Trebi-Ollennu is a [[Fellow]] of the [[Institution of Engineering and Technology]], U. K., and a Fellow of the [[Royal Aeronautical Society]], U.K. as well as a Senior Member of the [[Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers]]. He is also a Fellow of the [[Ghana Academy of Arts and Sciences]]. He has received multiple awards.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://samuelobour.com/2012/08/09/ashitey-trebi-ollennu-the-ghanaian-who-helped-america-put-curiosity-rover-in-mars/#|title=Archived copy|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140814101428/http://samuelobour.com/2012/08/09/ashitey-trebi-ollennu-the-ghanaian-who-helped-america-put-curiosity-rover-in-mars/|archive-date=14 August 2014|url-status=dead|access-date=29 January 2015}}</ref><ref>[[NASA Exceptional Engineering Achievement Medal]]</ref> His individual prizes include:<ref name=":1" /> * NASA Exceptional Engineering Achievement Medal (2008) ''"For exceptional technical contributions to the Mars Exploration Rovers, providing comprehensive engineering support pre- and post-launch, including resolutions of rover anomalies".'' * Sir Monty Finniston Achievement Medal (2007) ''"For outstanding technical contribution to any field of engineering from the Institution of Engineering and Technology (IET), Europe's largest professional society for engineers;" "For outstanding technical contribution to the NASA's Mars Exploration Rovers mission''” * Outstanding Engineer Award (2007), from IEEE Region 6 (12 states of the [[Western United States]], ''"For exceptional technical leadership and ingenuity in diagnosing the [[Opportunity (rover)|Mars Exploration Rover Opportunity]] robotic arm anomaly culminating in a successful resolution of the anomaly leading to the continuing successful exploration of the surface of Mars in the extended mission;" "For exceptional service to the IEEE as a Guest Editor in organizing and publishing a special issue of IEEE Robotics & Automation Magazine on Mars Exploration Rovers, June 2006"'' * JPL Mariner Award (2006) from MER "''For outstanding leadership in the analysis and resolution of the IDD unstow anomaly on Opportunity Rover"''
Ollennu's team awards include: * NASA Group Achievement Award-Mars Exploration Rover Avionics Team, 25 May 25, 2004 * NASA Group Achievement Award-Mars Exploration Rover Flight System, Management and Engineering Team, 25 May 2004 * NASA Group Achievement Award-Mars Exploration Rover Project Operations Team, 25 May 2004
== Personal life == Trebi-Ollennu's uncle was the [[barrister]] and [[judge]], [[Nii Amaa Ollennu]] (1906–1986), elected the [[Speaker (politics)|Speaker]] of the [[Parliament of Ghana]] during the [[Busia government|Second Republic]] as well as serving as the Chairman of the Presidential Commission and acting [[President of Ghana]] from 7 August 1970 to 31 August 1970.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.judicial.gov.gh/history/list_lawyers/home.htm|title=Official Web Site for the Judicial Service of the Republic of Ghana|date=14 April 2005|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050414064831/http://www.judicial.gov.gh/history/list_lawyers/home.htm|archivedate=14 April 2005|url-status=bot: unknown|access-date=6 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://rulers.org/rulg1.html#ghana|title=Countries Ga-Gi|website=rulers.org|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070403074857/http://www.rulers.org/rulg1.html|archivedate=3 April 2007|url-status=live|access-date=6 June 2017}}</ref> His personal interests include various sports: [[Tennis|lawn tennis]], [[table tennis]], [[association football]], [[chess]], [[American football]], [[Track and field|athletics]] and [[test cricket]].<ref name=":1" /> His siblings are Flora Amerley Trebi-Ollennu, Roselind Amorkor Trebi-Ollennu, Ashitei Trebi-Ollennu and Emily Amaakai Trebi-Ollennu.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Trebi-Ollennu|first=Flora A.|date=6 May 2015|title=Stones Tell Stories at Osu: Memories of a Host Community of the Danish Trans-Atlantic Slave Trade by H. Nii-Adziri Wellington. (review)|url=|journal=Callaloo|language=en|volume=38|issue=2|pages=422–424|doi=10.1353/cal.2015.0045|issn=1080-6512}}</ref>
